message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. All other options do not fit with the symptoms described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest myotonic dystrophy type 1, which is caused by a CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is associated with ALS. Complete impairment of the dystrophin protein is seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Humoral immune attack against the endomysial blood vessels is seen in dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms in the patient point towards myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. The symptoms include muscle weakness and wasting, ptosis, muscle pain, and poor school performance. The other options involve different mechanisms and diseases that do not fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings are consistent with myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by the CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. The other options are not associated with the characteristic symptoms and findings of myotonic dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest the patient has myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. Options A, B, and C are not associated with myotonic dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. The patient’s poor school performance, size percentile, and muscle weakness are all consistent with myotonic dystrophy. Answers (A), (B), and (C) are not associated with myotonic dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest myotonic dystrophy, and among the options, only DMPK gene expansion can cause this condition. Apoptosis of lower motor neurons can cause spinal muscular atrophy, complete impairment of dystrophin protein can cause Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and humoral immune attack against endomysial blood vessels can cause dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including muscle weakness and poor school performance, suggest muscular dystrophy. The specific symptoms in this case, such as ptosis and high-arched palate, match myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. Options A, B, and C are not related to myotonic dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely underlying cause is myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. The muscle weakness in the face and hands, ptosis, and high-arched palate are typical symptoms of myotonic dystrophy. Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is seen in spinal muscular atrophy, complete impairment of the dystrophin protein is seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and humoral immune attack against the endomysial blood vessels is seen in dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including muscle pain, poor school performance, ptosis, and high-arched palate suggest myotonic dystrophy, which is caused by CTG trinucleotide expansion in the DMPK gene. Option (A) is incorrect because apoptosis of lower motor neurons would result in muscle weakness, not just muscle pain. Option (B) is incorrect because complete impairment of the dystrophin protein would result in Duchenne muscular dystrophy and present with generalized muscle weakness. Option (C) is incorrect because humoral immune attack against the endomysial blood vessels would result in dermatomyositis, which presents with rash and muscle weakness, not just muscle pain.
